description: From Middle English, from Latin agitatus, past participle of agitare (“to put in motion”), from agere (“to move”). Compare with French agiter. See act, agent.

verbs.description: agitate (third-person singular simple present agitates, present participle agitating, simple past and past participle agitated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disturb or excite; to perturb or stir up (a person). [from 16th c.]
examples: He was greatly agitated by the news.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to move with a violent, irregular action; to shake. [from 16th c.]
examples: It was a dark and stormy night; the rain fell in torrents — except at occasional intervals, when it was checked by a violent gust of wind which swept up the streets (for it is in London that our scene lies), rattling along the housetops, and fiercely agitating the scanty flame of the lamps that struggled against the darkness.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To set in motion; to actuate. [16th–18th c.]
(transitive, now rare) To discuss or debate. [from 16th c.]
(transitive, now rare) To revolve in the mind, or view in all its aspects; to consider, to devise. [from 17th c.]
